Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Phylogenetic patterns and processes of repeated morphological evolution in turtles
Award.AbstractNarration:
Modern biology was founded on Charles Darwin?s principle of ?descent with modification?. Closely related species share similarities in size, shape, and form of their body plans. However, in some cases, distantly related species also share similar traits. This exception to Darwin?s rule has puzzled biologists and raises the question: to what extent is evolution repeatable and predictable? This project will address this fundamental question by examining an interesting pattern of repeated evolution in turtles. Some distantly related turtle species feature similar anatomical modifications that allow them to close their shells when attacked by predators. The project will employ leading-edge molecular biology techniques to determine whether this pattern requires similar changes in genes that control embryonic development of bone tissues in these species.

Turtles are of high cultural and economic importance to societies worldwide. Yet, they are one of the most imperiled animals on the planet. This multidisciplinary project will train underrepresented undergraduate and graduate students to improve knowledge and raise public awareness about turtle diversity and conservation. This knowledge may also contribute to improving human bone health. Research materials will be available to the public through museums and online databases. Results will be disseminated broadly to K-16 and public audiences.

Project Outcomes Report

 

Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant: Phylogenetic patterns and processes of repeated morphological evolution in turtles

 

Over the last 210 million years, turtles successfully colonized and adapted to freshwater, marine, and terrestrial environments worldwide. This ecological diversification is reflected in the remarkable shell variation of living turtles, suggesting that processes governing the formation of the turtle body plan have evolved.

            As part of our study, we conducted one of the most species-comprehensive examinations of turtle development. We learned that the evolution of complex shell forms is underpinned by correlated changes in development of the shoulder blade and shell. This finding suggests that the seemingly static body plan of turtles has great potential to diversify, though by means that we have only begun to discover. 

            To further investigate the potential for turtles to diversify, we studied how genes influence the development of one of the most remarkable adaptations of the turtle body plan: shell-closing systems. Shell-closing systems have evolved at least seven times in unrelated terrestrial and semi-aquatic lineages. We focused on North American turtles of the Emydidae family, in which two unrelated lineages have evolved a type of shell-closing system that includes a complex synovial joint similar to the human knee or elbow. Remarkably, emydid turtles with shell-closing systems feature this type of joint on their shoulder blade.

            Our primary goal was to determine whether emydid species, Terrapene ornata and Emys blandingii, employ similar genetic solutions to similar ecological problems, i.e. a shell-closing system with a complex synovial joint. We learned that, as embryos, these species exhibit similar patterns of gene expression (which genes are turned on or off) during formation of their specialized shoulder blade joint. Intriguingly, we found that genes that control cell death were involved in the process of tissue breakdown, which leads to bone segmentation and joint formation. This transformation occurred unusually late in embryonic development and was enabled by the extraordinary capacity for bone tissue to “self-adjust” in response to physical changes in development (i.e. developmental plasticity).

            Our project addressed a central topic in phylogenetic and biodiversity science: Do unrelated species in similar environments develop similar traits using similar developmental processes? In our study system, the answer to this question was: "Yes". This is significant because studies of repeated trait evolution in animals rarely attempt to link evolutionary patterns of trait similarity to underlying processes that are often shared by distantly related species. Furthermore, our study is the first to clearly demonstrate the role of developmental plasticity in the repeated evolution of a skeletal trait in vertebrate animals.

            In addition to contributing to current understanding on how patterns of diversity are generated in nature, our study provides valuable information on how bone joints of animals are formed.
